item.title: This week in global development
item.description: This Week in Global Development is Devex’s podcast series covering the top stories from the global development sector.

item.title: ‘Every step a struggle:’ Nigerian woman with disabilities leads push for dignity and inclusion
item.description: A woman living with disabilities in a camp for displaced people in Nigeria is demonstrating why it is essential that people like her are included in society and how dignity can be protected even in the harshest places.

item.title: PassBlue’s New UN Crossword
item.description: The PassBlue UN Crossword: Are You Fluent in Diplomacy? Welcome to our new crossword puzzle, testing your knowledge of the 80-year-old international body that is well known but also misunderstood. The puzzle is meant to reinforce the UN's basic role in the world, which, as the US likes now repeat, is to maintain peace and security. One word in the puzzle sums up the main tool of the organization. Can you guess which one?

item.title: State Dept taps African faith groups for bilateral health deal consults
item.description: African Christian faith leaders gathered in Nairobi this week. While the U.S. State Department said it will leverage faith-based organizations in its new approach to global health, there’s concern over whether African governments will funnel money to them.

item.description: This week, experts offer guidance for those looking to pivot into philanthropy; the top organizations that emerged from our job board analysis of Africa; featured new job leads; and more.

item.title: HIV is not over in Asia-Pacific: A wake-up call from Fiji
item.description: Opinion: As Fiji’s epidemic surges tenfold, we need urgent action — scale up proven tools, embed care in primary health, and end stigma.

item.title: Are UK aid commitments to equality and localization failing in Sudan?
item.description: Can the U.K.’s aid system, built for big international delivery chains, actually deliver on its promises of localization and gender leadership in a place such as Sudan?

item.title: Egypt triumphs over centuries-old fight against trachoma
item.description: After over 3,000 years of battling the world’s leading infectious cause of avoidable blindness, Egypt has successfully eliminated the disease, offering hope to the 100 million people still at risk around the world.

item.title: Devex Newswire: Former USAID chief sees promise in Trump's aid rethink
item.description: Is it possible for foreign aid to successfully combine generosity with a country's own economic and security interests? Plus, the "magical" insect that could help battle malnutrition.

item.title: UN chief condemns Guinea-Bissau coup, urges restoration of constitutional order
item.description: The United Nations has strongly condemned the military coup in Guinea-Bissau, warning that the overthrow of elected authorities just days after national elections represents a grave violation of constitutional order and democratic principles.

item.title: UN rights office condemns ‘apparent summary execution’ of two men in the West Bank
item.description: The UN human rights office, OHCHR said on Friday that it was “appalled” by the “brazen killing” of two Palestinian men by Israeli border police in the West Bank, describing it as “an apparent summary execution.”

item.description: Myanmar’s planned late-December elections are unfolding in what UN rights officials describe as an atmosphere of fear, violence and deep political repression, with thousands detained and major parties excluded in a process that risks entrenching instability rather than restoring democracy.

item.description: Measles deaths have dropped by 88 per cent since 2000 – yet an estimated 95,000 people, mostly children, still died from the virus last year, the UN World Health Organization (WHO) warned on Friday.
